bibl.title: Letter from James Green to Robert Carter, 1717 November 4

div1.p: James Green writes to Robert Carter, November 4, 1717, to enclose a plat (not present) of Robert Carter's "Chappawomsick Land."

div1.head: James Green to Robert Carter, November 4, 1717
div1.p:
this Comes for Cover to the Inclosed And
to begg pardon for my long detainure thereof; I have nothing
I can offer for my Justification but what Looks So trivial tha[t]
I am forced to Confess mySelf Guilty; so hopes you will forgive
this Crime to one who shall be very proud to Obey your Commands
when Ever your Honr. will Overmore Confer them upon
div1.closer:
May it please your Honr.
Your Honrs.
most Humble Servt.
Jams Green

div1.head: NOTES
div1.note: Source copy consulted: Carter Papers (Mss 1C2468a7), Virginia Historical Society, Richmond. This is the recipient's copy. The address leaf bears the following: "To the Honourable | Robt. Carter Esqr. | These." RC has docketed the address leaf: "the Platt of my Chappawomsick Land | recd Jany 18th. 1717"; and a clerk also wrote a docket: "James Green. Nov. 4. 1717 | Inclosing the Plat of Chappawomsick | Land." Chappawomsick Creek drains into the Potomac River from the west, and was, in 1731, to become one of the dividing creeks between Stafford County and the new county of Prince William.
[1] James Green has not been identified.
